but that also is not the intended meaning.  It is true that there are sadhanas associated with each of the personal deities, but the teachings are not on the sadhanas per se, they are about the meaning of reality as represented by the deities.The eight principal personal deities of the system are of two types. First there is a group of five representatives of transcendence over the world.  They represent each of the five main aspects of buddha activity.  After them are the 'jig rten pa'i sde gsum three representatives of non-transcendent category.  The eight are: 1) འཇམ་དཔལ་སྐུ Mañjuśhrī in the form of Yamantaka, who is the body logo; 2) པདམ་གསུང Hayagrīva of the padma family who is the speech logo; 3) ཡང་དག་ཐུགས Yangdag Heruka who is the mind logo; 4) བདུད་རྩི་ཡོན་ཏན Am itakualin who is the qualities logo; 5) ཕུར་པ་ཕྲིན་ལས Vajrakīlaya who is the activity logo; 6) དམོད་པ་དྲག་སྔགས The curses, wrathful mantra; 7) རྦོད་གཏོང་མ་མོ The sorcerers, the Mamo; and 8) འཇིག་རྟེན་མཆོད་བསྟོད Worldly Praise and Offering.  Collectively the eight are called སྒྲུབ་སྡེ་བརྒྱད

.NOTE: This is an important term in the ཁྲེགས་ཆོད Thorough Cut path of the Great Completion and also in essence Mahamudra.  It means to keep and not lose, to maintain, སེམས་ཀྱི་ངོ་བོ the essence of mind that has shone forth in the practitioner's mind.  In these contexts it specifically means that no rational process or effort is being used to preserve it, rather the special instructions that go with the practice are followed to keep it just as it is.  This is also always applied to the ངང state, q.v., and the phrase ngang skyong ba
is a key oral instruction of these two practice systems.  II. <noun> 1)
.  2) <name> The Sanskrit

བསྐལ་པ་གྲངས་མེད་གསུམ: The Hīnayāna scriptures tell us that our teacher Buddha Śhākyamuni began his spiritual path under the Buddha known as the

and served seventy-five thousand buddhas up to the time of Buddha Rā h rapāla.  Over this period Buddha Śhākyamuni gathered the accumulations of merit and thus completed the first incalculable kalpa of his journey to enlightenment. Then, beginning with Buddha Sādhukara and continuing to the time of Buddha Indradhvaja, our teacher further served seventy-six thousand buddhas. This period represents the second incalculable kalpa of Śhākyamuni's path as a bodhisatva. Then, beginning with the time of Buddha Dīpa kara and continuing on through the time of Buddha Kāśhyapa, our teacher Śhākyamuni served seventy-seven thousand buddhas. In this final period, Śhākyamuni completed the third incalculable kalpa of gathering the accumulations. Then he took rebirth in the Tu hita heaven, from where he emanated into our world system as Buddha Śhākyamuni, the fourth buddha of this Fortunate Aeon.

.  Beings with deluded minds live in an overall existence of going from one rebirth to another.  The rebirths that they take are always within the enclosure of births that are produced by ignorance and experienced as unsatisfactory.  Since they always cycle around within this type of existence, the Buddha gave the name འཁོར་བ
to it.  This is usually translated as
these days but really does mean
འཁོར་བའི་ཉེས་དམིགས: No matter where you live it is unsatisfactory; no matter who you associate with it is unsatisfactory; no matter what activity you do it is unsatisfactory.; and moreover it is only ever the cause of such, therefore there is not one happy circumstance in it anywhere.

དགུ་བ: to bend forward deferentially or submissively
to bend over / be bowed forward
.  The verb is not the same as གུག་པ which has just the general meaning of

.  It is also not the same as འདུད་པ which is the general (and transitive) verb for one person to bow to another person or thing.  Rather, it is mostly used to refer to very deferential or submissive behaviour of the body.  In Tibet, one aspect of the culture was that a person could be called up before the དཔོན་པོ local leader (or other superior figure) and abused for their various errors.  When that happened, the lesser person had to stand in a very submissive posture: they had to lean the body forward from the waist and have their head bent and often they would have their hands joined palm together in a supplicatory posture.  They would speak if necessary in a very softened voice and in very respectful and submissive tones.  This bending forward in a deferential and / or submissive posture is called lus mdun du dgu nas sdod pa/
.  It is used equally to mean

The Bhagavat first, in the place of Varaāsi, at  i his Dropping in the deer park, for those to be truly placed into the Shrāvaka Vehicle, completely teaching the four truths of the noble ones, fully turned the amazing and wondrous dharma wheel to that time had not been turned in the worlds either of gods or humans, the worlds conducive to dharma for a first time.  That turning of the dharma wheel by the Bhagavat moreover was surpassed, was temporary, and was provisional meaning that became grounds for debate.

But then the Bhagavat, beginning from there no entitiness of dharma, beginning from no-birth-ness and no-cessation-ness, primordial-peace-ness, and naturally-perfect-nirvāṇa-ness, for those to be truly placed into all vehicles, turned with its precise distinctions the extremely amazing and wondrous third dharma wheel.  This turning of the dharma wheel by the Bhagawas not surpassed, was not temporary, was definitive meaning so did not become a grounds for debate.

an epithet used by Tibetans for the most realized lamas e.g., rgyal ba nor bu for the Dalai Lama, rgyal ba karma pa for the Karmapa, rgyal ba 'brug chen for the head of the Drukpa Kagyu, etc.  Note that rgyal ba rin po che is used as a general epithet for any of several great lamas (not only the Dalai Lama).  In this case the epithet does not necessarily mean that they have achieved perfect buddhahood but means that they really have conquered འཁོར་བ cyclic existence and hence are taken as true bodhisatvas of the Tibetan land. རྒྱས་པར་བཤད་པ: To have made / given an extensive explanation

.  The true noun form is རྒྱས་བཤད q.v.  1) In general, an explanation which is at length rather than in summary.  Tibetan tradition usually recognizes textual explanations as having either three or four levels; see རྒྱས་འབྲིང་བསྡུས་པ་སྙིང་པོའི་སྐོར་བཞི

.  Of them all, this rgyas par bshad pa is the most extensive level of commentary or explanation.  2) In particular, One of a range of terms used to indicate a certain level or type of presentation of a topic; see also མདོར་བསྟན་པ
.  This term refers to a main presentation or part of the main presentation of a topic given in the form of an lengthy explanation.There are several categories of
all of which are different ways of explaining a topic.  An

means an extensive explanation in general whereas a rnam par bshad pa complete explanation specifically means one that goes through a whole subject and treats it exhaustively.  An extensive explanation will probably include a detailed discussion of the topic however, the term བྱེ་བྲག་ཏུ་བཤད་པ specifically means
.  All of these explanation mentioned go through a subject at length.  Unlike them, a spyi bshad pa gives a
of any given subject; it goes through a subject explaining it in general features but not extensively, exhaustively, or in detail.These

type presentations stand in relation to shorter presentations such as སྤྱིར་བསྟན which is a general presentation that usually precedes an explanation of a subject or a མདོར་བསྟན synopsis that will always precede a main presentation or explanation of a subject.  For example, the first main topic of a subject might be presented in three parts like this: don dang po la/_don mdor bstan/_rgyas par bshad/_don bsdu ba'o/

The constellations through which the moon passes in her revolution round the heavens are called rgyu skar lha mo nyi shu rtsa brgyad, the twenty-eight goddesses, moving-stars, believed to be the daughters of the four guardian-kings of the world.  The constellations are thus named:- (1) tha skar Aśhvinī (dbyug gu); (2) bra nye Bharanī; (3) smin drug K ttikā the Pleiades; (4) snar ma Rohi ī (be rdzi be-rdsi); (5) mgo M gasiras (smal po); (6) Ārdrā, lag; (7) nabs so Punarvasū; (8) rgyal Pu hyā (rgyal stod = nabs so); (9) skag aśhe hā (ba); (10) mchu Maghā (rta pa) or rta chen with Regulus bright star; (11) gre Pūrvaphalgu ī or rta'u or rta chung; (12) dbo Uttaraphalguī or khra; (13) me bzhi Hasra or bya ma; (14) nag pa Citrā (or bya'u with Spica); (15) sa ri Svāti; (16) sa ga Viśhākhā; (17) lha mtshams Anurādhā or lag sor; (18) snron Jye h hā, or lde'u (with Antares); (19) snrubs Mūla, or srog pa; (20) chu stod Pūrvā āsādha; (21) chu smad uttarā āsādha or phul; (22) gro bzhin Abhijit; (23) byi bzhin Śrava ā gnyis; (24) mon gre Dhanasta or mon dre; (25) mon gru Śatavisā or sgrog; (26) khrums stod Pūrva-bhādrapada or (27) khrums smad uttarabhadrapada; (28) nam gru Revati or she sa Śesa.These names belong to the science of astrology / astronomy that originated in

has gained general acceptance as the appropriate term.  Note the distinction between brgyud and rgyud here.  Whereas rgyud indicates a general sense of continuity where something is passed down, brgyud specifically indicates that the transmission occurs from one person to another.  Thus for example, the correct spelling of the term snyan brgyud mentioned above is with brgyud not with rgyud as sometimes appears (snyan rgyud). .  2) For any being to enter the path to cessation, the person must first see clearly that cyclic existence is not pleasant but only dissatisfactory and then take the step of turn their mind away from it followed by the step of turning their mind towards obtaining emancipation from it.  That turning away from cyclic existence because of seeing it to be un-satisfactory and turning towards emancipation is called nges 'byung for the reason that one has turned one's mind toward obtaining the certainty of having gone to nirvāṇa mentioned in the first meaning.  Thus, although it can be seen why the common translation for this is
, it can also be seen that this is a very mis-leading translation.  Whilst

captures the fact of turning away from cyclic existence, it loses the meaning of turning towards that which gives definite release.  It is very important to note the term that Buddha used to describe this embodied the positive aspect; the English translation which is almost universally used of the term —

—leads to a negative connotation being put on a term that is nothing but positive.  Since the Buddha spoke of this in such a positive way, and since it is such a crucial term, it would be good to find a new translation that is more accurate both to the meaning and the spirit of the original.Also often called disenchantment, revulsion, aversion, etc., but note from the definition that these are incorrect translations.  It is true that those states of mind are implied by yid nges par 'byung ba but the real meaning of yid nges par 'byung ba is that one has become certain of how things are and hence has become positive of the direction that one will take.  Similarly, the following terms have been used as translations but from the foregoing definition it can be seen that none of them really capture the meaning properly:

Clarification: The three ancestral kings would offer as much gold as fits in a deerskin pouch to each Indian paita when they requested them to help the Tibetan translators in their endeavours to translate texts from Sanskrit into Tibetan.6. The feature of the greatness of the teachings: The translations of the past were completed at a time when the doctrine of the Buddha had reached its zenith in India. Furthermore, certain tantras did not even exist in the Indian Mainland, but were retained by bodhisatvas, accomplished masters, knowledge-holders and āki īs who had obtained their empowerments.  These were taken from pure lands and from regions of Jambudvīpa such as Si ghala and O iyāna in the West through the miraculous deeds of the great masters Padmasa bhava, Vimalamitra and others, and then translated (in Tibet). Thus, many teachings which were completely unknown to the scholars and accomplished masters of India arrived to become the meritorious fortune of Tibet.Furthermore, concerning the translations themselves: Since the translators of the past were emanations, they established the meaning correctly. Therefore, their works are easy to understand and, on plumbing their depths, the blessings are great. Translators of the later period however failed to render the meaning but made literal translations (merely) by following the arrangement of the Sanskrit texts.  Consequently, their stilted terminology is hard to understand, and on plumbing the depths the blessing is slight. Therefore, they are not the same.

The translator and chief editor was in those days an accomplished scholar who could be trusted.  Nonetheless, a translation had to be in accordance with Sanskrit poetry and grammar when putting it from the Indian text into Tibetan language or back (to check) from the Tibetan text into the Indian language. This was an extremely difficult task.  It meant that each translation had to be re-translated into Sanskrit and had to come out exactly right.  Each text must have been translated in co-operation between the Tibetan translator and the Indian scholar. Then that translation was revised and edited until it was flawless. And finally, the text was finalized as being an authoritative translation, by expounding and studying it. These are the reasons why the translations of the earlier translation period are truly trustworthy.

ཆོ་འཕྲུལ་རྣམ་པ་གསུམ: Three types of miraculous feats (of a buddha)
the three miraculous feats of a buddha
miraculous feats of showing up (what is already there)

First, a teaching buddha teaches by means of the three types of miraculous feats. With the miraculous display of the magical powers of his body, he emanates inconceivable light rays from the curled hair between his eyebrows, and so on, gathering thereby those beings needing to be tamed who have not yet been assembled as his entourage. Then, he covers the three thousand-fold universes with his tongue, and so forth, causing thereby the beings who need to be tamed, and who are now gathered as his entourage, to gain trust.

With the miraculous display of his all-communicating mind, he comes to know totally the minds, faculties, and the latent tendencies of those beings who need to be tamed and who are gathered as his entourage.

Then, with the miraculous display of his universally-corresponding speech, he expounds, through his melodious speech endowed with sixty aspects and in accordance with the individual language of each being-be they gods, nāgas, or others, the respective dharmas for taming whoever by whatever means.

The development of Tibetan Buddhism and Tibetan buddhist literature in the early spread happened because of the patronage of Tibetan kings of the time.  The kings of in power during the period of the early spread were the successors of a very ancient line of kings.  Many of them were supporters of the new buddhist culture in Tibet but three of them stand out as the great ones of its propagation.  The three of them became known as

.  All of them were important figures in the development of buddhist literature and the development of the Tibetan language that went with it.  The first of the three, King Songtsen Gampo was the cause of the new, Tibetan language.  The second one, King Trisong Deutsen was the cause of a massive translation project that resulted in most of the buddhist scriptures being translated into Tibetan.  That king had several sons, one of whom was responsible for the first revision of the language.  The third one, King Tri Ralpachen was responsible for the second revision, which was the most sweeping of the three revisions; it included a complete re-translation of all the exoteric buddhist texts that had been translated up to that time, and many sanctioned changes to the language.
the inauguration of a new system of language

About one century later, in the middle of the 8th century, there was a second noteworthy period in the development of Buddhism and buddhist literature in Tibet that happened under Trisong Deutsen.  Born in 730 A.D., he later ascended the throne and, under his royal patronage, Buddhism flourished greatly.  He brought the མཁན་ཆེན་བོདྷི་སཏབ༹ Abbot Śhāntarak hita and the great Guru པདམ་སམབྷ་ཝ Padmasa bhava to Tibet.  He built Samye Monastery to which he invited many paits from India and Nepal, and learned monks from China, too, and supported and encouraged many Tibetan translators who were sent there to work with them.  In particular, he established a huge translation project at Samye with the paits and translators and, over a period of years, caused a complete corpus of buddhist sūtras and tantras to be translated into Tibetan for the first time.  Because of his activities for Buddhism in general and because he was responsible for the first, complete translation of the corpus of buddhist literature into Tibetan, he became known as the second of the three great Dharma kings in the early period of Buddhism being introduced into Tibet.

The youngest of the four sons, Mutig Tsanpo, then ascended the throne in 787 A.D. at which time he received the name Tridey Srongtsen.  He also worked very hard to uphold and propagate the buddhist teaching in Tibet.  Many of the translators and païçits from his father's time were still present and the momentum of translation work with them.  This king invited more great païçits from India and Nepal to assist with the work and, under his patronage, it is said that the remainder of the sūtras and tantras not translated up to that time were translated into Tibetan.  A group of translators called the
are especially known in connection with the translation work of the time.

King Tridey Srongtsen died in 817 A.D. and was immediately succeeded by his son Tri Ralpachen who continued the family tradition of strongly supporting the buddhist teaching.  He performed many beneficial works for Tibet in general and, in particular, the Buddha's dharma flourished greatly under him.  It is recorded (see the quote in the next section) that he himself said that most of the buddhist texts of both sūtra and tantra had been translated already by his forebears, however the translations that had been made were inconsistent and contained terminology that was not standardized.  Therefore, he decreed that the translators should create standardized terminologies and methods of translation then use them to revise and create definitive versions of all of the translations done up to that time.  These things were done and the various improvements that were made to the language during his reign became collectively known as the second revision to the language.

Because of Tri Ralpachen's activities for Buddhism in general and because he was responsible for producing the fully edited and corrected, definitive translations of the complete corpus of buddhist literature in Tibetan, he became known as the third of the three great Dharma kings in the early period of Buddhism coming to Tibet.  The end of his reign marked the end of the early spread of Buddhadharma in Tibet.

The view of I and mine in regard to the five upādāna skandhas which are a perishing and impermanent collection of many things put together.  That further has co-emergent and all-labelled aspects: the first is that all sentient beings in every circumstance are thinking
; the second is that, due to attending a bad spiritual friend, the view of a permanent self other than the skandhas is seen, such as is found principally in the works of the Tīrthikas.

There are twenty subdivisions of the view of the perishing collection as follows.  The view that the form is self; the view that the form has a self; the view that the form belongs to myself; the view that the self is dwells in the form; and then in a similar way the four of feeling, perception, formatives, and consciousness are divided into four each to give twenty.

Of the ten suffix letters,The four ga, da, ba, and sa are male,The three nga, ma, and 'a are female,And the three na, ra, and la are neutral...

For the three male suffixes, no matter which name-base letter they are placed on, a vocalization of stronger sound is used; for the two females, a weaker sound is used, and for the three neutrals an intermediate, i.e., a moderate sound is used.
རྗེས་འཇུག་ཕོ་ཡིག: For the three male suffixes, no matter which name-base letter they are placed on, a vocalization of stronger sound is used; for the two females, a weaker sound is used, and for the three neutrals an intermediate, i.e., a moderate sound is used.
རྗེས་འཇུག་མ་ནིང: The intermediate vocalization of these three neutrals na, ra, and la, when they are present at the end of a name-base male letter whether they have a resuffix on them or not, and when they are placed after a neutral name-base together with a resuffix, is in contact with a stronger vocalization, so they turn to stronger.  For example, when in contact with a male letter name-base as in kun/_dkon/_bkar/_bkol/_skyal/_can/_gcerd/_bcold/_gtan/_bstand/_dpon/_spar/_dpal/_speld/_brtson/_btshird/_tsald/ and so on, and placed after a neutral namebase together with re-suffix, as in 'khond/_chard/_thard/_phuld/_tshard/ the contact is with stronger, so they turn stronger.
The above two, stronger and weaker, are changeable neutral.  The meaning of
is that if they come into contact with a stronger name-base, they turn to stronger and if a weaker one, they turn weaker so, since they do not maintain their form, they are spoken of as

When placed after the five name-base neutrals kha, cha, tha, pha, and tsha without a resuffix, there are no changes to stronger or weaker anywhere.  For example in mkhan/_'khor/_khal/_chen/_'char/_'chal/_mthun/_thur/_'thol/_phan/_'phur/_'phel/_tshon/_tshur/_'tshol/ since both name-base and suffix are neutral and since there is no male or female gender whatsoever, they are held to be
རྗེས་འཇུག་མོ་ཡིག: Similar to the division into three beings for males, the weaker females also are divided into the two subdivisions of stronger female and weaker extremely female.  First, both nga and ma with re-suffix are the stronger one, just the female, for example as in bzhengs/_gangs/_dbyings/_byams/_bsgoms/_rnams/.  Second, the endings, i.e., suffixes, first of nga without re-suffix, second of ma without resuffix, and third of 'a ending are extremely female examples of which are: mthong /_zhing /_gsum/_gtam/_bka'/_dga'/_mkha'/_mda'/.

སྙིགས་མ་ལྔ: The five degenerations: 1) The degeneration of views due to the decline in the virtue of renunciants means wrong views.  2) The degeneration of afflictions due to the decline in the virtue of house-holders means coarse-natured minds in which coarseness refers to strong and long-lasting afflictions.  3) The degeneration of sentient beings means the decline of body due to inferior shape and lesser size, the decline of merit due to lesser power and splendour, the decline of mind due to lesser sharpness of intellect, power of recollection and diligence.  4) The degeneration of life span due to the decline of the sustaining life-force means a decreasing life span until finally reaching the length of ten years.  5) The degeneration of times due to the decline in enjoyments means the decreasing Aeon of Strife.

བཏགས་པ: letters of the Tibetan syllabary are called btags pa.  Tibetan grammar allows compound Tibetan letters to be built by joining two or three consonants vertically.  To build the compound letters, the main letter of a མིང name, which is called the མིང་གཞི base of the name, can have certain letters super-fixed and/or certain letters sub-fixed.  Superfixes are called yig ge brtsegs pa
and subfixes are called yig ge btags pa
.  For instance, the compound letter kya is ka ya btags pa

.  Four different consonants may be used as sub-fixes: ya, ra, la, and wa.  When one of these consonants has been sub-fixed, the joined letter itself and the new combination both are called ya btags pa

Ignorance is like alienation, lying etc.,

Alienation and lying do not involve just not having affection or truthfulness or just being something instead of affectionate or truthful; rather, they involve a dissidence with affection and truth which becomes their very opposites.  Likewise, ignorance does not involve just not having the antidote insight, but is a dissidence with insight which becomes its very opposite.  Here, the antidote which is insight is insight into the genuine meaning, the egolessness, of a person.  Ignorance, the opp. of that, is the view of the transitory which grasps at an ego of a person.

Of the two—grasping at a mistaken view regarding the genuine meaning and just being obscured regarding the genuine meaning—ignorance is said to be the latter.  In short, of these two conceptual minds of wrong understanding and of non-understanding, ignorance is the conceptual mind of non-understanding.  However in turning away from that the chief antidote is said to be the prajñā which realises egolessness.

If obscuration is categorised there are two sorts; obscuration regarding karma and its result, and obscuration regarding the meaning of suchness.  By the first we collect sa skāras which send us into lower rebirths.  By the second we collect sa skāras which send us into upper rebirths.

.  II. <noun> Cognate to the verb meanings above.  Translation of the Sanskrit [MVP]

.  Note that ston pa has the specific and special meaning of someone who has understood a truth and then shows the way of that truth to others; it does not refer to a conventional teacher and is never used to indicate that sense.  For example, one of the epithets of Śhākyamuni Buddha is ston pa
.  There it does not mean

in the common sense such as school-teacher but in the sense of the founding teacher who first (ston pa) elicited a particular way / system / religion.  This is a difficult point of translation because modern Western society has a very different concept of the whole process of learning and the relationship to the teacher in that process than that operative in the Buddhist tradition that was passed from India to other countries including Tibet.  For example, the word for

in the common sense would be dge rgan but even this carries a sense of the student having respect for the teacher which is largely lost in Western society.In regard to this [HNL] gives the definition,

However, while that definition might be true in Nyingma Tantric literature (from whence the definition is derived) it is not true in general.  Every tradition of philosophical and religious thought has a person who first elicits the teaching and shows it to others.  Such a person is always called the ston pa

of the tradition.  Thus the ston pa founding teacher for the Buddhist tradition in this age is ཤའཀྱ་ཐུབ་པ Śhākyamuni Buddha.  In the time of Śhākyamuni Buddha there were many other philosophical and religious traditions, each with its founding teacher.  Of them, the Buddha himself picked out six main teachers who he stated were teaching a system that was not in accord with reality; they are called the མུ་སྟེགས་པའི་སྟོན་པ་དྲུག
q.v.  2) The epithet ston pa is often applied to the Buddha in conjunction with one or more of the སངས་རྒྱས་ཀྱི་མཚན many other epithets of the Buddha, e.g. in ston pa de bzhin gshegs pa

.  The term is generally used to describe things which are perceived as completely different or distinct entities.  For example, a mouse and a bear are tha dad pa
.  In grammar, verbs are either tha dad pa
.  The definition of transitive and intransitive verbs in Tibetan grammar matches the definitions of English grammar very closely, hence the translations as
are very accurate.  A ཐ་དད་པའི་བྱེད་ཚིག transitive verb is that in which an agent performs an action on an object that is tha dad pa

from the agent.  On the other hand, intransitive verbs are those in which the agent is not separate or distinct from the object of the action.  For more about transitive / intransitive verbs, see the relevant section under བདག་གཞན
of transitive verbs and see བྱ་བྱེད

is seriously inadequate as can be seen from the above analysis, therefore a new term is required.  Some translators in recent years have recognized this and have been using alternative, pre-existing English words instead of

.  Ultimate has the first problem that its meaning does not match the meaning of this term.  Secondly, ultimate is an exact match for the Tibetan term mthar thug pa.  Finally the Tibetan term mthar thug pa which should be translated as
often appears side by side with this term in Tibetan texts and each of the two does provide its own, specific meaning which must be distinguished from the other.  The term
at least has the first half of the meaning of this term, however, it misses the main meaning of

; it is not sufficient. Having looked for years, I can say that there is no currently existing word in the English language that can function as an equivalent of this term.  There has been talk of newly constructed terms to fill the gap for this and other terms that are not fulfilled by the existing vocabulary of the English language.  Based on the above analysis of the meaning of
—an analysis which is supported by all major Tibetan writers of all schools, I propose

as a new word that could provide a very good translation.  This new word represents the Sanskrit and the Tibetan that copies it, well; it has roots that match fairly well the roots of the original so that even the etymology works; it is fairly euphonious (compared to other possibilities); and in particular, it works well in tandem with my proposed translations for the paired term ཀུན་རྫོབ

q.v.  II. In general, the term is used to describe the kind of reality that appears to non-deluded minds.  In the sutra system, any appearance for all beings in cyclic existence is categorized as ཀུན་རྫོབ

.  In the sutra system, the aryas who have transcended saṃsāra, with the exception of the buddha, see dam pa'i don the superfactual in their mnyam bzhag equipoise on emptiness however, their སྣང་བ appearances in rjes thob post-attainment are still ཀུན་རྫོབ

because they are still a product of obscuration.  The situation for a buddha is a little bit more difficult and gets into deep points of philosophy.  A buddha has appearances for himself and appearances for others.  Of the two, some say that the first is regarded as dam pa'i don the superfactual and the second is regarded as ཀུན་རྫོབ

, though there is a lot of argument over it.  It would be too much to try to discuss it here.Note that this term is not pejorative; it refers to the non-fictional realities that non-deluded beings experience.  More than that, it is complimentary in the sense that the term is used only for the realities of spiritually advanced persons. དུས་ཀྱི་འཁོར་ལོ: Outer Kālachakra is described like this.  'Time' is one year.  'Cycle' is the two journeys, South and North, and in each of these journeys there are six months making twelve and in each of those a division into waxing moon and waning moon results in twenty-four.  Each of those additionally divided up into fifteen gives three hundred and sixty.  The reason for calling this
is because that kind of approach makes a time cycle(1) of one year or a time as-many-as-there-are-kalpas cycle(1) and hence the name.

Other Kālachakra is described like this.  When of development and completion stages it is connected with development stage, it is connected with the purities: the complete purity of outer and inner time comes as the single kāya; the complete purity of the two journeys comes as the two feet; the complete purity of the outer and inner twelve shifts comes as the twelve shoulders; the complete purity of the sides comes as the twenty-four hands; the complete purity of greater and smaller day-and-night comes as the three hundred and sixty joints, and so on.  In the completion stage, 'Time' is all dharmas being one in the essentiality which is unchanging bliss and that having the excellence of all aspects starting with the two journeys of method and prajñā, the six branches, twelve true meanings, and so on is 'cycle'. The Bhagavat first, in the countryside of Vārā asi at  i his Dropping in the Deer Park, for those to be genuinely placed into the Śhrāvaka Vehicle, completely taught the four Noble Truths and so the dharma wheel which is amazing and wondrous and which previously had not been turned in the worlds conducive to dharma—either devas or humans—was turned perfectly for the first time.  That turning of the dharma wheel by the Bhagavat moreover is surpassed, is temporary, is provisional meaning that becomes a place which is a basis of debate.

to be tormented / anguished but although these are technically correct, they do not usually convey the spoken sense of the word.  E.g., in English, when speaking of someone who is distressed over the death of loved one, we would rarely say that someone was
or
; we would usually speak of their
and perhaps their
or

.  In fact, these kinds of words translate this verb best in most such circumstances.  On the whole, this verb needs to be translated according to the meaning and not as a literal translation.Furthermore, the verb, even in the usage of suffering, has a sense of wanting with it.  The mental distress that comes from longing for a loved one; or the torture of being out in a very hot heat and wanting not to be there; or the longing to be free from the disease or sickness that is causing pain.  Moreover, the verb when used to indicate mental distress usually indicates misery that is felt in the mind at the heart; all Tibetans when describing the meaning of the verb always put their hand over the heart as they describe the mental distress.On the whole, this verb needs to be translated according to the meaning and not as a literal translation. Śhamatha has the experiences of bliss, clarity, and no-thought associated with it and knows of subtle sensations, as fine even as a hair's quiver, within the non-distraction; those things are not there in the no-thought blankness:

means that from the experiences alone of śhamatha's bliss, clarity, and no-thought one gets side-tracked into the three realms.There is also a type of bliss, clarity, and no-thought which is not temporary experience but which is the realization of the three.  When the ultimate reality of one's mind has been realized then these three are present not as temporary experiences but as the expressions of the ultimate reality of the mind.  The བཀའ་བརྒྱུད lineage makes the distinction very clear in its texts on ཕྱག་རྒྱ་ཆེན་པོ Mahāmudrā and the same distinction is also made clearly in the Nyingmapa tradition's texts on རྫོགས་པ་ཆེན་པོ Great Completion.  There is another famous two-line verse regarding this which Padma Karpo again uses in the [DDT]
Bliss, clarity, and no-thought—these threeAre the very peak of meditation,

.  The object is the dharmas of form, sound, and so on that will be referenced.  Minor is referencing in the inferior desire realm.  Major is referencing of the form realm from the first dhyāna to the fourth.  Measureless is referencing of the formless realm from āyatanas of infinite space up to without yet not without cognition.

.  1) One of the five object determining སེམས་བྱུང mental events q.v.  There is no specific term for this mental state in English, however it means for the mind to be inclined towards something and to have intention to pursue that thing.  Thus it implies interest in and intention towards.  It includes aspiration as described in the verb description but aspiration does not refer to fully formed content of mind.  The term means that state of mind in which mind has taken interest in, is turned towards, and pursues after something.  (Thus) it is not yearning or zeal as some have given.  It is more like

.  E.g., the Buddha said chos rkyen nas 'byung ste/_'dun pa'i rtse la gnas/

.Normally, the term is only used for the final, indestructible qualities that result when an ordinary being's three doors are purified by practising the path to enlightenment.  The partially developed path qualities are called the gsang ba gsum three secrets and the impure, undeveloped qualities are called སྒོ་གསུམ three doors of body, speech, and mind.  The term is sometimes used to refer to both the final and path versions but never to the ordinary, impure aspects.  If it is used to refer to both, then the final version is distinguished from the path version by adding the term mi phyed pa to refer to the final versions; see རྡོ་རྗེ་མི་ཕྱེད་གསུམ

, a technical term in Buddhist གསང་སྔགས secret mantra practice of a deity.  1)
.  A particular stage of the practice in which, the visualization is gathered back into its source as part of the conclusion of the practice.  2)

.  In the term འཕྲོ་བསྡུ where it is the name of a particular section of the main part of some deity practices.  II. <noun> 1) In reference to books which are abridgements, abbreviations, condensations, summaries, or compendia.  Hence

.  The use of bsdus or bsdus pa in a book title commonly means that the book is a condensation of some subject or text but it can also mean that the text includes the entire meaning of some other subject or text.  2) Abbrev. of the name of a specific text; many texts have this as part of their names and sometimes an author will refer to one of these texts simply with the word sdud pa e.g., ཤེར་ཕྱིན་སྡུད་པ is commonly referred to just as sdud pa; there are others, too.  3)

གནུབས་སངས་རྒྱས་ཡེ་ཤེས: He was born in the early part of the 8th century AD to his father Salway Wangchuk of the Nub clan and mother Chimmo (a woman from mchims) Tashi Tso.  He lived to 130 years of age.  As a child he was called Dorje Tritsug.  At seven years, he learned to read and write from the son of Odrel Pal.  He took ordination from Khenpo Bodhisatva and heard a great deal of dharma teaching from him.  He received a great many empowerments and oral instructions from Padmasambhava then went to practise at Dragyang Dzong where, due to persevering at meditation, he gained attainment.  The Crystal Mirror of Tenets says,

.  After that, he went to India and Nepal about seven times where he requested and received instruction and oral transmission of many holy dharmas and so the middle transmission of the Nyingma teachings came down through him and he was responsible for causing the sutra, tantra, and mind teachings to flourish and spread.  He was one of the group of the twenty-five, Lord and subjects.  His well-known disciples were: Kulung Yontan Gyatso, So Yeshe Wangchuk, Pagor Lonchen Phag, Ngan Yontan Chog, Sru Legpa'i Dronma.

Emptiness having the excellence of all aspects has two explanations, one explained in sūtra and one in tantra.  The sūtra system makes the prajñā of the natureless three cycles into the emptiness and makes the completely white dharmas of generosity, and so on into the aspects possessed by it; the Highest Continuum says,
The Kālachakra tantra system makes all-encompassing, great-bliss wisdom into an emptiness that possesses all of the aspects, as many as there are, of the animate and inanimate worlds.

the three avenues to the རྣམ་པར་ཐར་པ complete emancipation

As explained before, if the producer, the cause, and the fruition, the thing dependent upon the cause, and dharmas that essentially have the nature of cause and fruition are thoroughly investigated with correct reasoning that examines for the absolute, then not even a particle of nature is found to exist for them.  They are characterized by the three marks of liberation.

If investigated in relation to the fruition, using the reasons of existence and non-existence or arising and cessation, we will find that there can be fruitions arise in dependence on causes and conditions.  However, since those fruitions will not be existent, non-existent, both, or neither, and so forth, they are also unborn and so cannot be wished for meaning that they cannot be prayed for or aspired to.
Thus, in the absolute, conventional cause, effect, and entity are dharmadhatu having the three marks of liberation.  It is properly said that their entity is that of the absolute.

རྣམ་པར་དཔྱད་པ: analysis in which something has been analysed to determine what it is by examining the རྣམ་པ surface attributes of the thing using བློ rational mind to do the analysis.Whether as a verb or noun, this term has the specific sense that a rational analysis has occurred.  Through this type of analysis, the subject of analysis is comprehended and defined as being such and such on the basis of the rnam pa attributes of the thing (not the ངོ་བོ thing itself) as known through blo rational mind.  This contrasts with the other type of analysis called ཡོངས་དཔྱོད in which something is not known through rational analysis relying on attributes but is known through direct perception (non-rational assessment) of the ngo bo entity itself.  In other words, rnam par dpyad pas rnam pa'i cha nas bzhag pa rational analysis defines something on the basis of the attributes and yongs dpyod pas ngo bo'i cha nas bzhag pa overall analysis defines something on the basis of what it is in fact.The distinction between the two analyses is important when determining the view of various Buddhist schools.  There is some debate about which applies where but according to the བཀའ་བརྒྱུད Kagyu school of Tibetan Buddhism, the rational analysis that examines attributes is used to determine the view in the first two turnings of the wheel and the non-rational analysis that examines the entity is used to determine the view in the third turning of the wheel and in the tantras. .  Appearances are not only restricted to what appears to the five senses but are the appearances, whatever they might be, of any of the six senses.  As such, this is an important term in Buddhism.  Some maintain that it is difficult to translate but

captures it very accurately.  There is the point that some Buddhist systems have the view that the objects known by the senses are external to mind whereas some systems maintain that all things are mind.  In the former case,
works without debate.  In the latter case, such as in the Mind-only School and in the tantras (ཕྱག་རྒྱ་ཆེན་པོ Mahāmudrā and Great Completion), since the
are none other than mind being seen by itself, some translators maintain that this term should be translated as

translates the term perfectly.  To translate it another way forces a specific meaning on the word which is not present in the original. for explanation.  The dying person is conscious only of a spaciousness filled with white colour, like space struck by sunlight, hence the name.  It corresponds to the re-absorbtion of the white element which is connected with the dynamic dimension of appearance as opposed to emptiness.  The white element is a maintained as a droplet in the crown chakra during life.  At this point it separates and travels down into the heart centre, where it will later join with the red element. Then, in connection with the newly created Tibetan letters that prevailed as a single standard, the King invited a number of great experts to Tibet: the Chinese Hāshang Mahādeva, the Indian Āchārya Kusara, the Bra min Shangkar, the Kashmiri Tanu, the Nepalese Śhīlamañju, and others.  With Lotsāwas Thumi Sa bho a, Darmako ha, Lhalung Dorje Pal, and others they translated the 'dus pa rin chen tog gi gzungs, the Ratnamegha Sūtra, and others then, with that knowledge, translated the one hundred thousand verse Prajñāpāramitā.  Principally though, they translated the twenty-one sūtras and tantras of the Avalokiteśhvara cycle.

This text by rdo grub rin po che Dodrup Rinpoche is a very famous commentary of the Nyingma tradition that covers, in detail, all the basic principles of the Mahāyoga path as set forth in the root Mahāyoga tantra, the རྒྱུད་གསང་བ་སྙིང་པོ. A person who abides in the fruit of once-return practises the path of non-return in order to attain the fruit of non-return.  Because of connecting with the fruit of once-return through persevering in meditation, the practitioner connects with the possibility of and so is a candidate for non-return.

ཕྱིར་འོང་ཞུགས་པ: a candidate for the fruit of once-return

A practitioner who abides in the fruit of stream-entry because of persevering in their meditation in order to attain the fruit of once-return, becomes a person who enters onto once-return.  At the point in time when the practitioner completely abandons the six afflictions, he moves onto abiding in the fruition of once return.

.Note that the phrase gong du 'phar ba has the sense of a sudden step or steps up whereas gong du 'phel ba has the sense of a steady increase.  In the example above, gong du 'phar bzhin du 'gro/, the meaning is that something is jumping from one level to another level continually, so that it is continually stepping up; this is different from gong du 'phel ba where there is a general, continuous or smooth increase.  Sometimes this distinction is quite important, e.g., in texts on meditation. .  3) The sense of pushing and nudging and hemming in is used in grammar to indicate the application of any one of the five prefixes when building a ming grammatical name.  See the noun below.  II. <noun><adj> Cognate to the second meaning of the verb.

.  A term used in grammar.  This is the name given to a སྔོན་འཇུག prefix letter when it has been written in position before the མིང་གཞི name-base letter of a མིང name.  It is described with this term because the prefix letter fronts up to the name-base letter, pushing into from ahead and hemming it in.  It hems in the name base letter because, grammatically speaking, a name base letter must have a རྗེས་འཇུག suffix letter written after it before it can be a word.  Therefore, the suffix effectively fronts up to the name base letter and hems it in between itself and the suffix which has to be written in the word and which brings up the rear.  This
name is given to a prefix in contrast to the suffix letters which are called the མཐའ
letters for the name.  The prefix letter in its role as a འཕུལ་ཡིག
is called the འཕུལ་རྟེན in grammar, meaning the particular letter which sits in and provides the
i.e., prefix, for the name.  E.g., bas 'phul

Tibetan scholars make references to the existence of more than one hundred Sanskrit commentaries on the text, most of which have been lost over the centuries. However, ten Sanskrit commentaries have been preserved in their Tibetan translations in the Tangyur since the time of བུ་སྟོན Buton, who established his Tangyur compilation at ཞབ༹་ལུ་དགོན་པ Zhalu monastery in 1334.  Of the ten, only a single complete commentary still exists in the Sanskrit language; it is the Bodhi-caryāvatāra-pañjikā  written by the Indian scholar Prajñākaramati.  A fragmentary anonymous Sanskrit commentary on the Bodhicaryāvatāra from Nepal has not yet been analysed and published.  The numerous commentaries on the text written by Tibetan scholars were not included in the Tangyur but were published separately.
The Indian scholar Sarvajñānadeva and the monk Paltsek, translator and chief editor, (translated), edited and finalized (this text) based on editions from Kashmir.

Later, the Indian scholar Dharmaśhrībhadra, the monk Rinchen Zangpo who was translator and chief editor, and Sakya Lodro, corrected, re-translated, and finalized (this text) in accordance with editions and commentaries from the Indian Mainland.

As becomes apparent throughout the text, contrary to popular assumption, the recension incorporated into the Tibetan canon is significantly different from the Sanskrit version edited by Louis de la Valle‚ Poussin and P.L. This would seem to refute the contention of Crosby and Skilton that the canonical Tibetan translation by Blo ldan shes rab (Ngok Loden Sherab, inserted in the quote) was based on the Sanskrit version available to us today.

When the great Tibetan scholar Buton was working on his commentary to the Bodhicaryāvatāra, he wrote in the colophon that he was unsatisfied with his copy of the third translation by Ngok Loden Sherab because he discovered numerous discrepancies between the translation and the Sanskrit text and commentaries he had available to him. .In Sanskrit, when a word is composed, it starts with a root which is then modified by additions to and / or modifications of the original.  E.g., a noun is modified in various ways to produce the singular, dual, and multiple plural versions of the noun.  E.g., a verb root is inflected to give the various participles of the verb.  E.g., a noun is modified in specific ways to produce the eight cases of a noun.Tibetan language, unlike Sanskrit and English, is a totally un-inflected language.  There are no
in Tibetan language in the sense referred to by this term.  Consequently, there is no རྣམ་འགྱུར

defined for the language, either.  Thus, this word is not found in Tibetan grammar texts when defining the language, except to mention this difference, which is one of the key differences, between Sanskrit and Tibetan grammar.  The term is occasionally seen in Tibetan texts where it seems to indicate that there is a

in Tibetan but in that case it is just borrowing a concept from Sanskrit grammar and applying it loosely to Tibetan language.  For example, in Sanskrit, a noun root is modified in specific ways to produce the singular, dual, and multiple plurals.  This is the true case of a

.  In Tibetan, there are noun words in the language by definition.  These are in the singular already.  To turn them into the plural, they are not modified to give a variant of a root.  Rather, they have another, special word written after them that causes the plural meaning to appear.  Tibetan texts sometimes say that this is like a
being modified but they only mean

.  Grammar texts themselves point out that the noun is not a root that is modified.  Rather, it is left as it is and another term is put after it to show a change of meaning.  In Tibetan grammar, this is referred to as a ldog pa gyur
, not a byings rnam 'gyur modification of a root.  E.g., nyi ma
is singular.  To make it plural it can have rnams put after it to produce  nyi ma rnams

.  In Sanskrit, this would not happen; a byings root for all of the forms of the noun, singular, dual, and multi-plural, would be modified to produce three different words, the noun in each of the three degrees of plurality.Furthermore, in Sanskrit, a verb is always given as its root byings and that root is then modified in structure (declined) to obtain the various tenses, the various cases, and the various new words that can be built from that root.  It is similar to a verb always being declared in the infinitive in English grammar and then having the various transformations of that root listed as the various participles.  However, in Tibetan, there is no such thing as a byings which is defined for verbs and which is then modified (declined) to give the various tenses.  Rather, Tibetan simply has different tense forms for a verb which are predetermined as a group without reference to a
byings from which the various tenses are produced in a methodical fashion.Furthermore, whereas in Sanskrit cases are built by taking the byings and then modifying it to give a case form of the byings

The sounds of the letters each have a སྐྱེ་གནས production place which is the basis from which the sounds of the letters are produced.  The production place is the basic cause of the sounds, like the housing of a bell.  The byed pa producer is the cause of the sounds being evoked from those places, much like the striker of the bell is the cause that evokes the sounds from the housing of a bell.  A particular effort is required to make a bell sound and likewise, each of the letters has a particular རྩོལ་བ effort which is needed to produce that sound.  The effort is a condition for the production of the sounds, like the hand is the condition needed to actually produce sounds from a bell with its striker.  There are different traditions of Tibetan grammar with differences in how the production places, producers, and efforts are defined.  According to the tradition of སི་ཏུ་ཆོས་ཀྱི་ཉིན་བྱེད Situ Rinpoche, there are five producers [SGC]:

Those five with a sa ending are the third case, 'agentive terms'.  The five connectors gi, and so on with a sa ending are the third case, terms of the doer, which means that whatever object the case sign is applied to itself is doing whatever is to be done whether the verb is adjacent to or distant from it, as for example in: mig gis bltas/ where the verb is adjacent to what performed the action and mig gis shel rtse'i rtse mo nas phyogs thams cad du yang dang yang du legs par bltas so/ where the verb is distant from what performed the action.

དབུ་མ་ཐལ་འགྱུར་བ: Consequence Middle Way.  Translation of the Sanskrit

.  The name of a Buddhist system of philosophy belonging to the sūtra ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོ Mahāyāna.  It is one of the two main systems of philosophy of the Mahāyāna.  It is the higher of the two and is thus the philosophical system with the highest view of all the views presented in the sūtras.  The system is also known as the ཐལ་འགྱུར་བ
system and a person who follows it is a དབུ་མ་ཐལ་འགྱུར་པ

q.v.Unlike all lower schools of Buddhist philosophy, which maintain that the view can be presented by explanation to the student and through logical syllogisms, the Prasa gika Madhyamaka maintains that the final view can only be presented to the student by logic that shows the student the absurd consequences of any view that the student might put forth.  Prasa ga ཐལ་འགྱུར is the Sanskrit word meaning logical system of showing the consequences—and the absurdity thereof—of any position.  By using prasa ga, the

of any view being held in mind is shown as absurd and the person who thus has their view shown as absurd has the chance not to correct their view but to drop it altogether and to arrive at the view which is beyond views.  Using this method, the student or opponent, whatever, is drawn to an illumination of the truth in their own mind rather than being given the truth.  Thus this system relies on the destruction of all views through showing the (absurd) consequences of any view and specifically does not put up a view of its own.  Thus the name is often translated as
དབུ་མ་པ: follower of the Middle Way.  Translation of the Sanskrit
.  The name given to someone who follows the དབུ་མ Madhyamaka or Middle Way system of philosophy.  Such a person is one of གྲུབ་མཐའ་སྨྲ་བ་བཞི
q.v.  There are three main types of Madhyamaka view and hence three main types of followers of it: see དབུ་མ་པ་གསུམ

Generally speaking, in letters there are both vowels and consonants; letters not included in that definition do not exist.  From among those included, the language of self-governed, snowy Tibet has for the requisite Āli, four indicators ai, au, ae, and ao of the function of a vowel.  There is also, in non-explicit form aa.  The Kāli grouping of consonants are the thirty letters from ka to aa.

འབྱེད་སྡུད: Separation-inclusion
terms of separation-inclusion

gam ngam dam nam bam mam 'am ram lam sam and tam separate and of multiple items where they are being separated out of one basis, as in bum pa'i rgyu ni gser ram/_dngul lam/_zangs sam/_rag gam/_rdza las bya 'o/
.  They are also placed to have the meaning of inclusion of multiple items which are being put into one basis, as in gser ram/_dngul lam/_zangs sam/_rag gam/_rdza las bum pa bya'o/
either is or is not
either exists or does not exist

Where there is a forceful da, tam is obtained, as in: phyin tam/_gyurd tam/_tsald tam/.  When there is no ending 'am is obtained, as in: kha'am/.  And when it says, The others are applied to be concordant with the word's ending, it means that it must be applied so that there is concordance with whatever suffix is at the end of the word, as in: stag gam/_bzang ngam/_yod dam/_yin nam/_lab bam/_bsam mam/_mtha' 'am/_shar ram/_gsal lam/_byas sam/.
such-and-such has the components this and this and this.
this and this reduced to
or to

and the connectors performing these two functions effectively act to produce a list in the same way.  Note how the classic example given above of gser ram/_dngul lam/_zangs sam/_rag gam/_rdza las bum pa bya'o/ can mean either
or
.Note how there is also the possibility of these terms functioning as
in relation to linking verbs.  II. Separation and inclusion are two of the five functions defined in Tibetan grammar for the དང connector.  These two functions for dang are exactly the same as
functions shown above for the eleven connectors gam and so on on but they do not include the additional function of separation of linking verbs i.e., they do not include

etc.Thus, the term dang can be substituted in the examples above with no change in meaning e.g., bum pa'i rgyu ni gser dang /_dngul dang /_zangs dang /_rag dang /_rdza las bya 'o/ has the same meaning as given above.  However, dang is usually used a little differently than the eleven connectors.In standard Tibetan usage, when dang is used to separate multiple items of a list, it is usual to place it just once after the first item in the list and then string all of the remaining items of the list together.  This is similar to the usual English style of writing a list where the members are written sequentially but with the last member of the group separated from the others by
.  E.g., the above would usually be written bum pa'i rgyu ni gser dang /_dngul zangs rag rdza las bya 'o/

.  Alternatively, to provide more clarity, dang is placed once after the first item of the list as above but then ཤད shad's are placed after each item of the list in order to separate the items, which is effectively the equivalent in Tibetan of writing a comma or semi-colon after each item of the list.  E.g., bum pa'i rgyu ni gser dang /_dngul/_zangs/_rag_rdza las bya 'o/ with the same meaning again.  Only when the sense

has to be explicitly provided will the dang be written after each member of the list.  This should be understood when translations are being made; just as English has its means of emphasis, etc., when making lists, so Tibetan does too.  The use of an explicit dang after every item in these kinds of lists should be translated with
because that is the sense being deliberately introduced by the writer, just as much as an English writer would resort to using

after every item of a list for the purpose of emphasis.Alternatively, when buddhist texts were being translated from Sanskrit and the Sanskrit used the equivalent of dang and placed it after every item of the list, then the Tibetan would reflect that and have a dang in each place.  When Yangchen Druppa'i Dorje defines these two functions for the dang term in his [JWL] (the italics are quotes from the root text) the examples he gives are from classic, Indian buddhist texts that have been translated into Tibetan with the consequent use of a dang in every position:
The so-called
is placed to give five meanings.  It is placed to give the meaning of inclusion into a basis of separation at the end, as in mig dang /_rna ba dang /_sna dang /_lce dang /_lus rnams ni dbang po'o/
.  It is placed to give the meaning of the separation from a basis of separation present at the beginning, as in dbang po lnga ni mig dang /_rna ba dang /_sna dang /_lce dang /_lus po/

མ་ཅིག་ལབ་ཀྱི་སྒྲོན་མ: In the sacred place of Akani h ha, the palace of dharmadhātu, from the heart centre of the great mother Samantabhadri, also known as Vajrayoginī, also known as Vajranairatmya, also known as Jetsun Tārā, a single ray of light emanated and, at its tip, an inconceivable, immeasurable mansion together with a seat manifested in a dimension of Akani h ha.  In the centre of that mansion manifested the dharmakāya great mother surrounded by unfathomable numbers of buddhas and bodhisatvas.  From the heart centre of the great mother, tamer of the maras, ཁྲོས་མ་ནག་མོ Black Wrathful Female manifested as five deities who were seated in the palace over the centre of Oiyāna, the country of the  āki īs.  From the heart centre of Tamer of the Maras, Wrathful Female, the ākinī Serlingma, chief of a ma ala of five deities, manifested then descended into the Oiyāna's Ghandhola palace.  In order to benefit migrators, sentient beings, she appeared after 107 successive lives in the places of gods and men, as Machig Labdron.  Furthermore, she had two births in Tibet as Gyaza and Palza.  Those two coalesced into one was Yeshe Tsogyal after which four manifestations came forth: Machig Zham, Shelza Dron Chigma, Zhang Cham Drochungma, and Labkyi Dronma.This Machig in an outer way is Ārya Tārā, in an inner way is the Great Mother, in a secret way is Vajrayoginī, and in a very secret way is the ཁྲོས་མ་ནག་མོ Wrathful Black Female.  Also, having manifested in the Buddha's retinue as Gangadevi, she showed the way to arouse bodhicitta.Now, what was said concerning her?  As it says in the mdo sde dvangs snyigs 'byed pa

as enumerated in Longchenpa's sngags kyi spyi don tshangs dbyangs 'brug sgra pp. 27-28, they comprise: 1) three tantras representing the body, speech and mind of buddha-body གླང་པོ་རབ་འབོག (mind), གླང་པོ་ཆུར་འཇུག (speech), and སངས་རྒྱས་མཉམ་སྦྱོར Buddha samayoga (body); 2) three tantras representing the body, speech and mind of buddha-speech རི་བོ་བརྩེགས་པ, padma dbang chen, and Candraguhyatilaka; 3) three tantras representing the body, speech and mind of buddha-mind rtse mo 'dus pa, gcig las 'phros pa, and གསང་བ་འདུས་པ Guhyasamaja; 4) three tantras representing the body, speech and mind of buddha-qualities སྒྲོན་མ་འབར་བ, bdud rtsi sa ma ya 'bum, and Śhrīparamādya; 5) three tantras representing the body, speech and mind of buddha-activity dpal phreng dkar po, ma mo rgyud lung, and bid yo ta ma la 'bum sde, and 6) three tantras representing of body, speech and mind of all these in general ཐབས་ཀྱི་ཞགས་པ, དམ་ཚིག་བཀོད་པ, and གསང་བ་སྙིང་པོ respectively.

མན་ངག་སྡེའི་རྒྱུད: The tantras of the Upadeśha section were brought to Tibet mainly by pa ita Vimalamitra and Guru Padmasa bhava.  Some of the major tantras of the Upadeśha section, which belong to the ཡང་གསང very secret or snying thig (Nyingthig) Heart-drop sub-division, according to Gyurmey Tshewang Chodrub and Padma Ledre Tsal are:A) The seventeen tantras མན་ངག་སྡེའི་རྒྱུད་བཅུ་བདུན Seventeen Tantras of Upadeśha Section q.v.B) Two Other Major Tantras:i) ae ka dza ti nag mo khros ma

.There are two other important categories of scriptures in the very secret section of Upadeśha section known as the Upadeśha category of teachings.  They are as follows.  According to padma las 'brel rtsal Padma Ledre Tsal the first is the snying thig (Nyingthig) Heart-drop teachings which contain the essential instructions of the Seventeen Tantras and the Wrathful Ekajati tantra.  It was brought to Tibetan by Vimalamitra and became known as the bi ma snying thig
.  The second is the snying thig (Nyingthig) Heart-drop teachings which mainly contain klong gsal 'bar ma'i rgyud
.  It was brought to Tibet by Padmasa bhava and became known as the mkha' 'gro snying thig
.Longchen Rabjam wrote a volume of commentarial and supplemental texts on Vimalamitra's Heart-drop known as bi ma yang tig
and one volume on Khadro Nyingthig known as mkha' 'gro yang tig
.  He also wrote a volume on both Nyingthigs known as bla ma yang tig
or yang tig yid bzhin nor bu
.  These two root scriptures and two commentarial texts are known as the snying thig ya bzhi

མི་སྡུག་པ་སྒོམ་པ: contemplation of ugliness.  In the teachings of the lesser vehicle, the Buddha taught a meditation on ugliness for the purpose of overcoming the mistaken perception of the human body being beautiful.  He taught his followers to go to a cemetery and meditate on corpses in varying degrees of dissolution.  He picked out twelve types of increasingly decomposed corpse as the object for twelve meditations, all designed to produce the perception in the practitioner of the unattractive nature of a human body.  The meditations are named for the recognition of ugliness in a particular type of corpse.  The names of the twelve are: 1) རྣམ་པར་དམར་བའི་འདུ་ཤེས

The five letters ka and ca and ta and pa and tsa taken together are the ཕོ་ཡིག male letters.The five letters kha and cha and tha and pha and tsha taken together are the མ་ནིང་ཡི་གེ neutral letters.The twelve letters ga, ja, da, ba, dza, wa, zha, za, 'a, ya, sha, and sa taken together are the མོ་ཡིག female letters.The four letters nga, nya, na, and ma taken together are the ཤིན་ཏུ་མོ་ཡིག extremely female letters.The four letters ra, la, ha, and a taken together are the མོ་གཤམ barren letters.Achen is also named མཚན་མེད
.  Achen is not only a barren letter but since it has a sound effort that is exceptionally weak it is also named, i.e., called,

.)  The three types have successively higher objects that are referenced.  The type of referencing mentioned here is the highest type.  The term dmigs med in the name is a synonym for emptiness; it means that which cannot be referenced, since དམིགས་པ referencing by definition is only something that happens in conceptual mind.  Thus the term means that emptiness is referenced as the basis for the arousal of compassion or loving kindness.  E.g., see དམིགས་མེད་ལ་དམིགས་པའི་སྙིང་རྗེ

The seven treatises consist of: 1) a full commentary on the subject ཚད་མ་རྣམ་འགྲེལ Pramā avartika; 2) a medium length work on the subject ཚད་མ་རྣམ་པར་ངེས་པ Pramā aviniśhcaya; and 3) a condensed work on the subject the རིགས་པའི་ཐིགས་པ Nyaya-bindu.  Those three are like the root and the remaining four: 4) གཏན་ཚིགས་ཐིགས་པ Hetu-bindu; 5) འབྲེལ་བ་བརྟག་པ Sambandha-parakī ha; 6) རྒྱུད་གཞན་གྲུབ་པ Samtānāntara-siddhī; and the 7) རྩོད་པའི་རིགས་པ Vada-nyaya are like its limbs.

.The above discussion also explains the mark called ཚེག་དྲག q.v.The above discussion also makes it clear why a tsheg is not a dot and should not be called such.  A tsheg is a breaker that performs various break functions from weaker to stronger and appears in various forms from a dot-like glyph to a long stroke in relation to its function.Some Westerner scholars have said that the short tshegs have grammatical meaning and that different kinds of tshegs can be distinguished because of it.  This is a particularly strange idea.  In fact, the textbook Translating Tibetan Buddhism goes to extraordinary lengths to set up a system in which tshegs are stated to have all sorts of special meanings. as one of the ཀུན་ཏུ་འགྲོ་བ་ལྔ five ever-present mental events.  2)

as one of the ཕུང་པོ་ལྔ five skandhas.Feeling is the component of the dualistic perceptual process which is the production of a response to the decision that was made about an ཡུལ object of perception when it was རེག་པ contacted.  The response appears as an མྱོང་བ experience in the mind that the object is either བདེ pleasant, སྡུག unpleasant or བཏང་སྙོམས neutral.  These three experiences are called tshor ba bde ba
, tshor ba sdug bsngal
, and tshor ba btang snyoms
.  Feeling is only ever one of those only three experiences and the three taken together are called the ཚོར་བ་གསུམ three feelings.  These three

are further divided into being either mental or physical feeling but this simply categorizes whether one of the three feelings has been experienced in regard to an object known through mental or physical consciousness.Once a feeling has occurred sentient beings usually act on the feeling by producing the various ཉོན་མོངས་པ afflicted states of mind in response to it.  These then function as འདུ་བྱེད formatives of further possibilities of འཁོར་བ cyclic existence.  Thus, feelings are one of the prime causes in the production of cyclic existence.  Since the mental event of feeling is a crucial part of the process that drives sentient beings' cycling through births in deluded existence, it is the seventh of the རྟེན་ཅིང་འབྲེལ་བར་འབྱུང་བའི་ཚུལ་བཅུ་གཉིས twelve processes of dependent-related arising q.v. for more information.  And, because it is one of the keys to the continuation of cyclic existence, the Buddha highlighted it specifically by categorizing it as one of the key components of sentient being's psychophysical existence. མཚན་མ: .  Generally speaking a mark or sign by which something can be identified, e.g., [TC] gzhan dang mi nor ba'i ched du mtshan ma rgyag pa/

.  The conceptual token or mark of anything is the particular defining characteristic that appears to the dualistic mind for any object known by dualistic mind.  It is a conceptual structure that appears in the mind by which something is categorized or placed e.g., by the aggregate of འདུ་ཤེས samjñā q.v. for further discussion.  Since the presence of conceptual tokens in the operation of mind implies that the mind is a dualistic one, the term is often used in Buddhist texts as a way of implying the presence of བློ rational mind, and its opposite, mtshan ma ma med pa

chos can gyi snang ba ma lus pa thams cad chos nyid dbyings kyi nang du rang bzhin gyis nang gis rdzogs pa 'di la rdzogs shes pa/_'di'i ngang 'am 'di'i rgya las skad cig gcig rkyang ma 'da' ba ni chen po/
.As was common in the Indian tradition and the Tibetan one following it, the term

is used to indicate the grandest possibility.  Therefore the reality being described here is not merely that all things are complete within that reality but that everything possible does occur within that in its full expression without ever departing from it.  Hence, it is not simply a

but the grandest form of that in which there is a final state that needs nothing else.  Thus it is the grand or Great Completion.Furthermore, Jigmey Lingpa in the seminal work [TYL] explains the meaning very clearly: rdzogs pa chen po gdod nas rig stong mnyam rdzogs chen por slar zung du 'jug rgyu med pa

.  The name is not talking of perfection but of completion of all things in one single sphere.Further again, Padma Kalsang Rinpoche of Dzogchen Monastery in Tibet glosses rdzogs pa in this context as yongs su rdzogs pa or chags song ba, with the first term meaning total completion or gone as far as it can go and the second meaning happened or completed.  This clearly shows that rdzogs pa here does mean completion and not perfection.As a translator, I have noted the further problem with

that people often take it to mean that there is some final, beatific state because of the tendency people have to grasping onto theistic solutions.  Great Completion undercuts that; it does not crank up the theistic possibility.Note that, in this system of teachings, the name is more fully given as རང་བཞིན་རྫོགས་པ་ཆེན་པོ

.There is a very important point here.  The term
is used in buddhist literature to refer to beings who have attained the fruition of the Lesser Vehicle paths and of the Great Vehicle path.  The Buddha coined the term

specifically to differentiate the arhats of the who are also known as buddhas (śhrāvaka and pratyekabuddhas respectively) from the buddha of the Great Vehicle.  The buddhas of the Lesser Vehicle are buddhas but they are not complete buddhas yet, they are not yang dag par rdzogs pa really, truly complete buddhas.  A truly, complete buddha is a buddha who has obtained the highest possible form of buddhahood, which is the buddhahood that is the fruition of the Mahāyāna.  For this reason, it is most important that the term not be dropped or distorted during translation.  Furthermore, although the rdzogs pa'i is sometimes translated as
, the real meaning in the Sanskrit and the Tibetan, is definitely

.  A common epithet in Buddhist literature for nirvāṇa.  It refers to the attainment of peace that arises due to leaving འཁོར་བ cyclic existence.  In ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོ Mahāyāna literature it is sometimes used to refer to the peace of the arhat in a pejorative sense; the arhat abides in and is attached to the selfish peace of private cessation where the bodhisatva has moved passed that and engages the world fully, without selfish concerns for their own happiness. ཞི་བ་ལྷ: The Stanzas of the Compendium of Training

Traditionally, authorship of the Bodhisattva-caryavatara has been ascribed to the renowned Indian master Śhāntideva who is generally believed to have lived in the first half of the 8th century, although no definitive historical verification according to modern academic standards can be found at present.  In addition to the Bodhisattva-caryavatara, the Tibetan scholars ascribe the authorship of two further treatises, the Śhik hā-samuccaya and the Sūtra-samuccaya, to Śhāntideva, although the colophon of the Sūtra-samuccaya clearly identifies Nāgārjuna as the author.

The earliest known biographical data on Śhāntideva is given by Vibhuticandra in the 13th century. This Indian Sanskrit scholar came to Tibet in 1204 as part of the entourage of the famous Kashmiri paita Śhākyaśhrībhadra (1127-1225) and wrote a commentary on the Bodhicaryāvatāra in the Tibetan language. That commentary contains a short biography of Śhāntideva.

Variations on the basic themes of Śhāntideva's life can be found in the writings of Buton Rinchen Drup (1290-1364), Sazang Mati Panchen Jamyang Lodro (1294-1376), Sonam Gyaltsen Pal Zangpo (1312-1374), Mondrub Sherab, Pawo Tsuglag Trengwa (1504-1566), Tārānatha (1575-1634), Sumpa Khenpo Yeshe Paljor (1704-1788), Tsechok Ling Yongdzin Yeshe Gyaltsen (1713-1793), Khenpo Kunpal (1872-1943), Khetsun Zangpo, and others.

རང་རིག: q.v.This term is not used in the sūtra system; it is found only in the tantric system where it has great meaning.  The dualistic mind of cyclic existence, སེམས or བློ by definition only occurs through the karmic process of cause and effect.  However, the essence of that mind, known by many terms such as སེམས་ཉིད

, etc., etc. is held to be enlightenment itself, something which exists permanently and has a type of existence which is outside the realm of being produced by causes and conditions.  Something which self-produces itself exists in its own right without need of causes or conditions and this is termed rang byung
.  The knowing which is the kind of knower that is the essence of mind is this called rang byung rig pa'i rig pa
.  III. Meaning rang gi rig pa

.The six texts use reasoning to establish the profound view of the Mahāyāna in accordance with the Second Turning of the wheel of Dharma, and of the Madhyamaka Prasa gika view in particular.  Hence they are often referred to more fully as དབུ་མའི་བསྟན་བཅོས་རིགས་པའི་ཚོགས་དྲུག

.Note that some scholars do not accept that the Precious Garland is a collection of reasonings and therefore, excluding that, they regard that the texts of Nāgārjuna on reasoning are only a five-fold collection referred to as the རིགས་པའི་ཚོགས་ལྔ.  For more about this see རིན་ཆེན་ཕྲེང་བ
.Note that the name means a grouping which has six texts in it and which concerns reasoning.  The name has sometimes been translated as

རིམས: A general name for a whole class of diseases.  The name is derived from rim pa and literally means
.  In Tibetan medicine, there are five main classes of the disease.  Summed up in Western medical terms, they include i)
diseases both life-threatening and non-life threatening and ii) non-infectious diseases that spread throughout the body such as cancer.The term has been freq. translated as
but that is not really accurate.  These are diseases that

which includes any kind of plague but also includes the common cold, influenza which are not life-threatening; diseases like the mumps and measles which are serious but not necessarily fatal; and all kinds of malignancies which are fatal.Tibetans use the term in ways that correspond to Western thinking and in ways that do not.  Therefore it is important to have a sense of the ways in which it is used to use the appropriate sense as required e.g., in Tibetan descriptions of the གཉན་རིགས་བཅོ་བརྒྱད eighteen classes of Nyen disease q.v., several though not all, are described as rims nad

.  In this case, the term is not being given a vague usage like in 1) below but is being given the specific meaning of a type of disease that spreads and usually kills; some of these are malignancies included in meaning 3) below and some of them are infectious diseases that seem to spread over the body, and which are included in both meanings 2) and 3) below.  1)
in the general sense of serious diseases that take over humans and kill them, infectious or otherwise. 2)
exactly the same as འགོས་ནད with exactly the same sense as Western medicine.  This includes all fatal and non-fatal disease that can be caught from another person.  3)

ལ་དོན: su ra ru du na la tu are the seven types of la-equivalent.  Those connectors are called the seven different la equivalents.  For what purpose are they used?  They are used for five purposes: as with shar phyogs su 'gro/
in case two, 'a function performed'; as with rtar rtsva byin/
in case four, 'necessity and purpose'; as with lha khang du rten gsum yod/
in case seven, 'place of support'; as with 'od du 'tsher/
in the internal division 'identity' of case two; and as with nyi ma'i 'char kha ru 'gro/

in the internal division 'events of time' of case seven.  Their mode of application is as follows.  sa gets su—an ending sa gets su as in:_g-yas su/_las su/.  ga ba and forceful da get tu; ga ba and forceful da endings get tu, for example, 'gag tu/_lag tu/_rgyab tu/_'gab tu/_kund tu/_sgyurd tu gsol/_tsald tu gsol/.  nga da na ma ra la get du—those six endings get du, for example: steng du/_bshad du/_mdun du/_lam du/_gser du/_dpal du/.  'a and no ending get ra and ru; when 'a is at the ending position and when there is no ending, ra or ru—whichever is suitable—is obtained as in: rta madr/_rta mda' ru/_khar/_kha ru/.

.Since Tibetan culture has contacted Western thought, the term has come into general use to translate terms like
, and so on.  It is also used to translate
in the sense of diseased cell, such as a cancer cell.  This kind of understanding did exist within Tibetan medicine from ancient times (see below).  However, this meaning, of a

or a creature microscopic in size is not seen very often except in medical texts or texts that use medical terms; the term in earlier times was mainly used to mean something visible, a creature of the small invertebrate type as mentioned above.    i) In Tibetan medicine, it is used for a whole range of very small things, which modern medicine would equate with everything starting from

, and ending at small worms and other like creatures that cause disease.  Note that this is an ancient term, coined well before Western medicine had the means to differentiate all of these small things.  The term covers worms and similar, disease causing insects and animals, which can be differentiated by the eye and also covers everything smaller than that.  In the latter case, the term really equates with the English
in the broadest sense i.e., a small factor that is inimical to the being it invades and which is the basis from which disease appears.  Diseases caused by these tiny factors are called སརིན་ནད

When used in this sense it has to be understood as equivalent to འོད་གསལ་བ luminosity and translated appropriately.  This is so important that it is given its own entry below.  2) To be clear in the sense of being unobscured, free of any obscuring factor.  This term is often used in conjunction with other terms to indicate the unsullied clearness of something.  i) It is used in reference to an unsullied, open state of mind, a lucidity of mind.  In particular, there are many མྱོང་ཚིག experiential terms that incorporate it to express the various states of clearness of mind that arise when the obscuring factors of mind are removed.  These terms are met especially in the meditation instructions of the vajra vehicle.  Unfortunately, the basic meaning has often been misunderstood and these terms have been translated with English words referring to the play of light e.g.,

.  However, that does not fit at all with the meaning of gsal ba; it means an unsullied, unobscured openess of mind as opposed to indicating a connection with light or radiance.  E.g., the term གསལ་དབ༹ངས

is used to describe states of mind that are very free of the usual obscuration and ignorance of conventional mind.  ii) It is used for physical objects.  E.g., the same term gsal dvangs is used to describe things such as water that are without any obscuring or sullying factor, no sediment or other kind of dirt in them. because their individual sounds make clear (in the sense of manifest, one of the meanings of གསལ་བ) a particular letter of the lettering set.  Then, in relation to those basic manifesters, the vowels are literally called དབྱངས

because they are tones which are added to the fundamental sounds of the consonants, to make the complete sound of a letter.  There are thirty consonants in the Tibetan lettering set, see གསལ་བྱེད་སུམ་ཅུ

.  Any kind of sacred principle that someone puts their trust in.  C. As an epithet for beings in the human world who are seen as higher than oneself.  A human in a very high position such as a king, or with great power over others, would be given any one of several epithets containing the word lha by Indians and Tibetans.  E.g., kings were accorded godly status in India and Tibet.  The āryā sa gha of the buddhist world are also referred to as gods.  E.g., lha rjes su dran pa refers to recollection of both the gods of the desire realm and to the āryā sa gha who are of very high position compared to ordinary humans.  II. <adj>
